text: LCI. Uit de fles geschonken. Heerlijke Belgium-style stout: gerookte mout, koffie en hop, licht rokerig. Prima stout/dark ale

12oz bottle. Very dark brown, beige head reduces to a thin collar. Enticing aroma of fresh roasted coffee, hints of cocoa. Flavors start with coffe then become more chocolate toward the medium, warming finish.

12 oz bottle. Pours brown with tall, creamy, beige head, nice lacing and lovely carbonation. Aroma is of herbal hops, toasted malt and coffee. Body is medium and slightly crisp. Taste is of toasted malt, coffee, chocolate, dark fruit and herbal hops. Finish is long and bittersweet. Overall good brew.

Growler from Monroe Super Buy Rite in Englishtown, NJ. Translucent cola brown color is topped by a large frothy tan head. Faint roasted malt nose hints at ash and charcoal. First sip yields sweet roasted malt flavor that touches on coffee and chocolate. Picking up notes of dark candi sugar, cocoa, tobacco, raisins, burnt wood and magnolia leaves. Yeasty, smoky, Belgian funky yeasty notes in finish. Sweet, dark and intriguing. Delicious and soulful.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2017 Lovely ebony black stout. Silky on the tongue, notes of smoke, coffee, sweet chocolate and caramel. One of the sweeter stouts I?ve had. Overall, it?s good, with everything I enjoy about a good, black stout. From a bottle gifted by a friend. I?ll pick it up when I see it again.
The beer has weak aroma. The yeast taste is buried behind dark chocolate malt which is pretty harsh.The flavor is quite complex and it is interesting. I am just not sold on it.
Light roasted smell...Almost no smell...Taste is much more bold....And good sweetness...Warming smooth malt...Light roastiness...Medium complexity...Good mouthfeel

November 25th, 2014 - Allagash Black is black, front to back, though the the foam wasnt really stacked. With a sniff, the beer I attacked, rich with charcoal and wet stone, backed with a little chicory too. The flavor was packed with alcohol and light raisins, though lacked a heavier palate. Instead the carbonation was jacked, almost rough on the aftertaste.

A Stout which makes in the sweetness, share round by roasted, with notes of licorice, dark chocolate and toast. Bitter is on the roasted coated by earthy and grassy hop. Silky texture and long and roasted finale with grape and a touch of sweetness.

Guess I never had this so grabbed a bottle probably a tad old. Browner pour. Nose is burnt coffee. Taste of roasted malt, chocolate, cofffee ground, earthy, prunes, licorice. Creamy mouthfeel little burnt toast on finish.

12oz bottle. Pours dark brown with a tiny beige head. Aroma is somewhat metallic, yeasty, and with a little coffee coming through as it warms. Taste is toffee malt, chocolate, some coffee, a little dark fruit, and a good amount of yeast. A touch of pepper. Lightly roasty with a bitter hop finish. Medium body. Moderate carbonation. A little watery but a pleasingly oil mouthfeel overall.

Room-filling aromas of yeast malt and licorice. Pours a deep black brown with a thin tan head. Big flavors of sweet coffee and chalk well balanced. Mild carbonation with an oily mouthfeel. Complex with a nice distinctive style. Very good.

Bottle from the brewery. This is a very complex beer -- its got some similarities to a Dubbel, with a raisin bread sweetness that reminds me of some of the best Belgian dubbels, but it also has a roasted malt character that reminds me of Guinness. Fruit esters from the yeast, before it finishes quick and clean. Its almost like someone brewed a stout with berries...

I poured it from the bottle into a glass. It pours dark brown with a fluffy, beige head and lacing. The aroma is roasted coffee and dark fruit. The taste is coffee, raisin, some chocolate, and spice. Theres less chocolate than advertised. I dont mean that as a bad thing though. Its really smooth and nicely balanced. I like the Belgian twist to this. It sets it apart.

Bottle from New Beer Distributors, Manhattan, New York, USA. A black coloured pour with a healthy off white/beige head on top. Roasty, malty, chocolate aroma. Tastes similar, roasty, malty, chocolate, hint of coffee. Lovely stout from Maine.

Appearance: Bottled 5/7-2015. Dark brown, almost black. Good amount of light tan head.
Aroma: Dark malt, roasted. Slight coffee.
Taste: Dark malt, roasted, slightly burnt. Some burnt bitterness.
Bought: Drinks of the World (Online), 355 ml, CHF 7.50
Info: 10/9-2016, BB: 30/11-2016 (according to importer)

Tap pour at Blaze in Bar Harbor, ME. Pint glass. Black with nearly tan head. Half finger. Aroma of dark fruit blended with roasted nuttiness. Hints of smoke and chocolate as well. Taste reminds me of a Belgian dubbel combining forces with a traditional stout. There is a definite tart, Belgian raisin and plum influence. Dark chocolate bitterness comes in at the end. Assertive aftertaste that lingers. Very enjoyable beer. Bet on black.
Joint oUT of my comfort zone with a Belgian, but pretty good without the sweet Belgian flavor.

Achète lors d un voyage aux usa, Biere de couleur noir avec un peu everfesssance et le col est couleur moka . On na des notes de chocolat et de ttorrification. C est où on goûte le chocolat un peu Lait avec un côté de Israël le est quand même lèger . Bonne Biere

Proper stout nose, rich, roasted malts, dark coffee and a little yeast. Dark brown, opaque with tan foam. The taste is roasted malt and some coffee and chocolate come through with some moderate flavors of bread and yeast. Finishes with malty darkness. Overall very smooth and drinkable. Medium - heavy body with low - moderate fizz. Sampled at Wurst Party Ever 7 November 2015.

Deep reddish black pour that lets some light through. Big coffee, some chocolate, licorice, roasted malts on nose. Flavor carries same as aroma with flavors trading prominence through finish - has a pleasant boozy backbone. Some nuttiness and a nice bitter finish. Medium and slick mouthfeel.

4 oz pour on draft at Spacebar. Dark brownish black with light tan head. Aromas of dark chocolate, roasty notes. Tastes of dark chocolate, roasty notes, light licorice. Medium-full body with a dry finish.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2016 Bottle. Pours black with little head. Aroma is mild but nice, very roasty, caramel, dark malts. Flavour is quite complex, lots of dark malts, with a sweetish, bitter finish. Nice! Cant really sense the Belgian flavours....
Very roasty/stouty aroma, and nice white foam. it is like a really good dry stout with a bit of a sweet touch.

2016/06/25 - Pours a black colour with a foamy, khaki head that lingers and leaves moderate lacing. Aroma is yeast, toasted bread, roasted malt, coffee, light smoke and dark bitter chocolate. Taste follows nose; toasted bread, yeast, roasted coffee, nutty tones, earthy hops, bitter cocoa and just a hint of alcohol. Mouthfeel is medium and silky with sharp carbonation and a toasty, bitter finish. Lots of coffee and cocoa with minimal sweetness. Nice.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle into pint glass. Looks like weaker coffee, off-white lingering head. Slightly sweat nose, suggestion of raisins, some roasted malts deep in the background. In the mouth, mostly light malt. Not really getting the chocolate. A bit of bitter in the back. A decent, but oddly sort of dull stout.

Sample poured at Allagash. The pour is a reddish brown with a huge light tan head that falls to a film leaving all kinds of lace. The aroma is full of metallic malts. There is a light cocoa to it, but it is a little messy. There isnt a lot happening. The flavor is a little better, but not much. The malts are lighter and slightly roasted with a string metallic bit lingering on. The mouth feel is thin and watery with a light carbonation and slightly sweet aftertaste. This one is pretty weird, and quite disappointing.

Flight at Allagash with koleminer20. Aroma is roasted malt, wood, yeast, robust. Appearance is dark brown, light tan head, thin. Taste is roasted malt, wood, yeast, full-flavored. Mouthfeel is medium body, light carbonation, robust aftertaste. Overall, this one is pretty good.

Exactly what it should be. Looks like slightly flat coke. Roasted malt scent and some yeasty stale bready-Ness. Mouth is medium feel and not heavy in sugars, but enough to give rise to the taste buds. Taste is yeasty and roasted malt. Some nutty and earth tones. Tap

Bottle, packaged on 2/17/16. Pours an extremely dark brown with a slight tan head, moderate lacing. Burnt chocolate aroma, roasted coffee notes. Full bodied, velvety mouthfeel with a lightly bitter, tongue numbing finish. Excellent.

Dark brown almost black in color. Nice , tanned head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt and dark fruits . Moderate sweetness in taste with distinct hoppy notes at the end. I felt slight notes of Belgian yeast in it . Close to dry finish. Delicious beer.
Nice black pour with almost no head. Smells of chocolate/coffee/malts. Big flavor of bittersweet chocolate and a little smoke.
Tap. Mostly black with ruby edges, with a light tan head. Getting plum, fig, light roasted maltiness, some chocolate as well. Thinner to medium body. Pretty solid.

July 22, 2015. On tap at Allagash.
Black with a small tan head. Aroma is soft roasted malts, light coffee, some licorice, chocolate, notes of prunes and spices. Taste is light sweet malty and fruity, soft roasted coffee with a smooth bitter finish. Medium bodied, slight creamy texture, soft carbonation. 
Nice.
Restrained aroma in a brown black pour. An interesting combination of the best of Belgium - beer and chocolate - that is deliciously different.

Holy crap....this is great. Lots going on here. Dark dark brown, beige head. Dark fruit, coffee, caramel, toffee on the nose. More hop bitterness and Belgian yeast on the tongue...notes of milk chocolate too. Hybrid type beers often go horribly wrong....this is quite the opposite, well done!
Strangely Allagash Black is actually brown. Stick head/lacing. Brown sugar. Quite yeasty. Crusty toast. Hints of coffee. Dry.  Thx jow.

Pours a dark brown with a small beige head that leaves nice lacing. Nose is of roasted malt and slight dark fruits. Taste is of more dark fruits and light roasted malt. Atypical stout to me but maybe all foreign stouts were like that? Light sweetness in the finish. Medium body, medium-high carbonation. A fair stout but a bit weak by Allagashs standard.

Bottle - 12oz. Pours an opaque black body with a diminishing off-white foamy head. Nice malty/hoppy aroma with roasted coffee hints. Alcohol is very well hidden. Its robust, well balanced malty/hoppy taste carries roasted coffee, oaky, and some black pepper notes. Ends with a long, sharp bitter/roasty finish. Well done.
Dark brown pour with tan head. Aroma mainly abbey type yeast/ spice but coffee becomes apparent as it warms. Roasty and light spice flavor, anise, some chocolate, average mouthfeel.
Black with nice carbonation and tan head. Molasses dark chocolate and bread. Clean finish.

Malty chocolate for the scent. Nice deep rich dark black color. Taste is of chocolate and barley just like its brewed. Full body with medium carbonation. This could be my next goto stout. Not a big allagash fan even though Im from Maine. This is one of your best brews.

Not bad for a Belgian. I don't like the flavor of Belgian yeast, so it's a little tough to get past that. However, the chocolatey malt is very good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a billowing tan head. Malty and somewhat metallic smell. Big roasty malt up front and throughout with a bit of heat at the end. Okay stout, much better when Ive had it on tap.
Tap at Allagash Brewing Company, Portland. Colour is clear dark brown with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Dark fruits, chocolate, softness and roasted malts. Very interesting fruity stout.

Draught @ Black Eyed Sallys: This one pours a fairly opaque black color. There was just a bit of a tan head that left a little lacing. Good nose. Some chocolate, roasted malts, breadiness. The taste is very good. Belgian ale meets stout. Chocolate, some roast, breadines, faint dark fruits, maybe a hint of raisin.
Dark brown with a minimal beige head. Aroma is chocolate, brown sugar, and toffee. Taste is sweet with some molasses, toffee, and caramel. Like a liquid Heath Bar. Hellz yeah. Overall very tasty.

Bottle into a Belgian ale glass. Roasty, yeasty aroma. Very dark brown appearance. This stout has quite a bit of complexity, with nothing in the mix being too overwhelming. The balance of yeast, coffee, chocolate, dark fruit and sugar flavor is subtle and well done. Medium body with a creamy mouth feel and a bit of a bitter coffee finish. A decent brew.

Very dark brown to black color, light brown head - Aroma of dark chocolate, coffee, maybde some hints of ash, rather earthy hops - Taste is medium to heavily bitter - medium to full body, rather creamy mouthfeel, average carbonation - long and bitter finish. Nice.

A true crossover brew, this offering from Allagash features both stout and Belgian aspects, with a strong roasted coffee appearance and flavor, along with a sweet Belgian yeast contrast. Some chocolate cocoa flavors as well. Mouthfeel is only an average smoothness with a slightly bitter roasty finish. I found the flavor profile exceptional but everything else is just par for the course.!Decent and different, seems like it has weaker points but a distinguished beer overall.

This is a dark, almost black beer, with a foamy tan head. Aromas of roasted malts, chocolate and dark berries. Rich taste of chocolate, coffee dark raisins. Not too bitter with a creamy, full mouthfeel. A very good stout with enticing aromas and a rich, complex taste. Excellent.

330ml bottle served in a tulip glass. Pours a deep black color forming a creamy and solid tan head with good retention but only few lacings left in the glass. Nose is roasted and sweet with strong notes of dark chocolate, licorice, candi sugar and roasted malts, of course. Grassy hops profile. Flowery. Taste follows the nose, sweet and roasted upfront taste. Notes of dark chocolate, licorice, candi sugar and roasted malts. Grassy hops. Medium bitterness. Heavy body. Medium carbonation. Roasted malts and dark chocolate in the aftertaste. Good drinkability. Strong Belgian character.

I don't know why this has good reviews? No aroma light bottle and sweetness. Mouthfeel thin. Peppery taste bitterness alight astringent flavor. Not my thing. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle in LA. Pours deep black with ruby tinge, off white head. Roasted malt and some hop sourness on the aroma. Chocolate first, coffee and distinct astringency on the finish. Not sweet at all, moderately dry and bitter finish with a little hop aroma. Medium carbonation, very creamy, medium body. Not sure if the Belgian yeast is contributing any character, but its a nice stout.

No aroma. Dark. Malty and roasty and slightly sweet. Better than expected. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark brown, stout body, but fruit of Belgium comes through, grapefruit and orange

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From a bottle to a snifter. Pours a brownish black with a thick beige head. The nose is phenomenal. Coffee, chocolate, wood, bourbon, all balanced with the sweetness of a belgian yeast. Taste is chocolate and vanilla with a bit of smokey wood. Round, smooth and sweet finish. Wonderful beer!

Free! Taster at the source. Pours nearly black (surprise) with a beige head. Aroma is dark chocolate, spent coffee grounds. Flavor is dark chocolate, but mostly over extracted coffee. Over extracted coffee bitter in the finish. This needs to spend some time in a whiskey (or rye) barrel.

Bottle, pours black with a tan head. Big & creamy, roast malts and chocolate, vanilla, coffee. Smooth, rich palate that is very full and long, its a great tasting beer with a lovely, smooth palate, but the finish has a bit too much sweetness for me.
Flaske 12 fl oz spandert av Rune. Delt på Nerstranda 27 Okt 15. Svart med svakt rødskjær. Veldig lavt skum. Forsiktig sjokoladearoma. Smaken tørr. Litt sjokolade. Anonym.

355ml bottle, trade with Skinnyviking. Shared with Finn at his place. Deep ruby-red body. Bubbly beige head leaving lacework on the glassware. Very nice. Wood, earth, and brown malty aromas. Nicely roasted chocolate malty flavours together with dried fruits, herbs and wood supported by a discreet touch of yeasty fruitiness towards the ending. Fine bodied. Enjoying (Tromsø 27.10.2015).

Pours hazy dark brown with big creamy beige head. Aroma is mainly belgian yeast esters, with hints of dark chocolate and coffee. Taste of bread and roasted malts, bitter and light sour, some light metallic too. Medium body, quite lively carbonation, bitter finish.

Bottle. It poured a black color with a tan head. The aroma was of caramel, chocolate, grains and some spices. The taste was similar to the aroma with more caramel, chocolate, spices and malts all balanced with coffee notes. Very nice.
slight malt, light chocolate aroma. black in color with a nice foamy head. rich chocolaty, dark malts flavors. medium body with a smooth chocolate finish.
Big bottle bomber, nice un assuming label. Poured black with tan head. Aromas of chocolate and coffee. Taste of coffee and roasted malts. Very silky smooth mouthfeel. Wonderful toffee finish.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2015 Bottle into tulip glass. Aroma is cocoa, roasted malt, with Belgian yeast sour and some fruity esters. Appearance is dark, root-beer brown with 1/2 finger-width light brown persistent foamy head with decent lacing. Taste was much like aroma--medium sweet cocoa and roasted malts with mix of sweet/sour fruity esters. Palate is medium bodied with creamy/silky texture and average carbonation. Nice long finish like aroma and taste. Overall, this was yummy. Not an officianado of the style but, if this is representative, then I need to try more.

Tap at Allagash. It pours darkest brown with a thick light tan head. The nose is toasty, earthy roast, light spice, charred wood, plain chocolate and rivita. The taste is bitter, earthy roast, toast, molasses, candy sugar, dark fruit, spice, cardboard, rivita and chard stuff with quite a dry, earthy finish. Medium body and moderate, foamy carbonation. Too much rivita going on. Fair at best for my personal tastes.

Taster at the brewery but have drank this a million times since 2001 ish. Pours a deep burnt umber color with a touch van dyke brown on the edges and a finger of slightly khaki foam. Lots of roast, some underlying yeast complexity. Soft coffee undertones, plum, roasted grain, slight touch of anise and gentian root linger in the finish. Carbonation keeps it on the lighter side.

Pour is black with a frothy white head. Nose is fresh bread, some roastiness and a hint of fruity Belgian yeast. Taste is estery with distinct roasted notes and a long dark chocolate finish. Medium to low bitterness. Silky mouthfeel. Very smooth for such a high ABV. Great interpretation of a stout!
Chocolate nose with some yeast. Coffee flavor with a roasted grain finish. Heavy body, Chewy mouth folk.

Really good brew for a 7.5% brew. Very smooth in spite of the healthy carbonation on pour and moderate retention. Roasty chocolate a hint of dark fruit perhaps. Seas the sure whether to age this or not so split the difference and sat on it for 9months or so. Did I mention it was smooth.....soooooo smooth. Rebut for sur

Pour is dark brown with a light tan head. Nose is moderate roast, a bit of oily hop resin, notes of citrus, candied sugar and a touch of belgian yeast. Flavor is overly roasted, slightly bitter, citrus hop, lightly creamy with a hint of milk chocolate, light grainy yeast. Soft feel, high carb, creamy texture.
Appearance is black with light lacing. Aromas of roasted malts, brown sugar. Sweet initial taste, smokey, roasted malts like dark chocolate.
Reminds me more of a porter than stout in its body. Roasty nose, porter mouth feel. Fair amount of hops and bitterness.

Bottle from Cork 57. Deep dark brown body with medium tan head. Nose is malty, toasty, caramel. Taste is also of malts, caramel, spices, ginger. Creamy with pretty strong carbonation and some dark chocolate in the finish. Pretty good.

On tap at the brewery. Dark but clear black-mahogany, light tan head. Strong espresso notes, some lighter dark chocolate notes. Hints of caramel. Fresh earth. Decently bitter, fairly dry. Very long, dry, bitter finish. Medium body, some chewiness, not particularly creamy. Alcohol is understated but present. Good.

Poured from bottle into a snifter darkest of brown black with a thin tan head.
Aroma is roasty funky sweet.
Flavor is subtle chocolalte malted. A thin feel to the palate for a stout. Its nice but I wont head out for another bottle...

Drank from a nonic glass, poured from a bottle. Pours black with nice fluffy, light beige head, and a tiny bit of carbonation. Has aromas of roasted notes and belgian candy. Has a nice smooth initial taste that ends with a very, not very good bitter, dry finish. I expected more.
Pours black with a light tan head. Aroma is roasty. Taste is a nice balance of malt, Belgian spice, with a bit of roastedness. Nice light body. Tasty drink.

Great every day stout. Aroma like a chocolate covered espresso bean. Taste like a super smooth roasty oat forward stout. Well balanced. Great beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

For those who dont like an overly aggressive stout this the stout for you. ABV is not overpowering makes for a good year round stout. I would buy this again not on my top of the list beers but for sure an easy go to beer.

750ml bottle into English pint. Pours a deep, dark brown, minimal head, moderate carbonation. Bready nose with Belgian yeast, dark fruits, and a bit of dark chocolate. Rich and roasty. Full-bodied, slightly smoky-dry finish.

Pours clear deep dark brown with low light tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, raisins, brown sugar, very light citrus fruit notes. Taste is sweet and rich with Christmas spices, carnations and cardamom. Body is light to medium with soft carbonation.

Such a good beer. I got it in the 750 ml bottle. The 2 Row barley, torrified wheat and oats give is a silkey mouthfeel. The roasted and chocolate malt and the generous portion of dark caramelized candi sugar contribute to the apperance and aroma, and the Belgian yeast combines it all to such a great palate. 
I will be getting this one again..

Clear dark brown black colour, off-white head. Aroma of roasted malts, spices, cherries, light vanilla. Light sweet caramel flavour, light cacao, yeast, hint bitterness. Bit thin. Finish cacao, yeast, caramel.(from 355mL bottle @ home)

As Belgian style stouts go, this is a very well balanced beer. It is a very smooth drink that avoids any type of hoppy finish. If I came came across this at a bar I would for sure order 2 or 3 :-)

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at MacGregors Greece. Dark pour with minimal head. Nose is standard - dominated by roasted/toasted malt, a touch of chocolate. Mouthfeel starts oily and sweet then turns dry and grainy as it is held in the mouth. Interesting, I liked it. Chocolate malt taste in the palate.
Pours black with low tan head. Aroma of earthy, coffee and basement aromas. Tastes of roasted malt, sweetness and coffee. Full bodied. Good balance.

Aroma: basement aromas, earthy, coffee
Appearance: brown-black, clear, tan head
Taste: medium sweetness, lightly bitter, coffee
Palate: full body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish, 

Very good.

APPEARANCE - nice black body, super light head. NOSE - mostly Belgian on the nose initially. FLAVOR - surprisingly light flavor considering the advertisement on the bottle of roastiness. NOTES - good, but more like a Belgian than a roasty dark beer.
Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Taste follows. Full bodied. Good balance.
Taste is chocolate, brown sugar, and spicy Belgian yeast, which then fades into a coffee finish. Good.
Black dark black pour with tan head. Smell of dark roast and some Belgian beer type spices. Flavor if dark roast with a Belgian yeast finish.
Old rating. Dark brown pour. Slight smoke, Belgian, chocolate, spices, little thin and bubbly for such a dark beer.

Allagashs stout offering is an outlier in the style. Its smokey, yet it retains some of that familiar spiciness that Allagash borrows from Belgian counterparts. Pours black on black with a beautiful, pillowy head. One of my favorite Allagash brews and is 100% recommended to fans of Belgian beers and stouts.
Pretty good aromas of cocoa and coffee. Jet black with big foam head. Taste of coffee and cocoa as well good rich breadlike finish.
bottle. Near black with one finger head. Surprisingly thin pour for a stout, but has plenty of chocolate malt flavor and light belgian yeast. Decently complex. Would have this again.

Pours black, nice tan head. Aroma of coffee and licorice. Tastes of roast coffee and spice. Smooth creamy texture, nicely carbonated. A very pleasant surprise as I am not a big fan of Belgian style beers.
Dark brown to black with a 1 finger head. Very roasty aroma, sweet, coffee, creamy milk like aroma. Much too sweet for me. Coffee, cream, milk, roasted taste, some burnt sugars.
Poured from a bottle black with a sandy colored head. Aroma is of alcohol and slight coffee. Light and somewhat bubbly on the tongue, first hint is of coffee finishing with chocolate and malt.

Poured from bottle black with brown foamy head. Aromas of belgian yeast coffee and chocolate. Taste is sweet chocolate and cocoa with a smooth grain feel slightly bitter at the end. A drinkable but not memorable beer.
Pours black from a bottle with a small khaki head with large bubbles, quickly dissipating. Aroma is of licorice or anise. Flavor is a very slightly smoky coffee and cola. Good beer.

Off white head that is 2 1/2 fingers in depth and dissapates quickly. Mahogany Brown in color with that amber hues. Not getting much in the aroma, just some funky earth notes. The taste is better. The taste has a definite roasty character with dark chocolate present throughout. Also getting a nutty character in this beer. The mouthfeel is a little thinner then I would like. Not a bad beer, but I was expecting more.

Really dark brown pour with no notable head. Aroma of belgian waffles, sweet chocolate, a bit of sweeter fruit. Average carbonation, really clean effervescent finish. Taste of chalky grain, a bit of ashy/mesquite smoke, melon, malty chocolate, belgian yeast, deeply roasted coffee.

12oz bottle from Wegmans, West Seneca, NY. A hazy dark chestnut pour with a ring of beige head; oaty aroma with a touch of chocolate; silky milk chocolate taste, with a sweet grainy body, and a pleasant bitterness; the finish is dry with obvious alcohol and some coffee grounds.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2016 On tap at Thirsty Monk Downtown downstairs. Pours dark and imposing- decent head. Typical dark beer notes- roast, chocolate, coffee with the Belgian notes subtle but effective. Medium to big mouthfeel and really smooth. Perfect for a cold winters night. 
On Sankey Cask at Porter Beer over Thanksgiving.  Not as good as I remember, but that could be Mr. Noro talking.   The midnight Brett is so much better.  Maybe my palate wasnt quite ready for Belgian yeast.   Decent, but dont need to have this again.

Stout from Allagash with thin but stable, light beige head and pure black colour, not allowing any light to shine through. Very pleasant, quite strong, enticing aroma of Belgian chocolates, coffee, banana, cocoa powder, raisins, dried orange peel, dates, candi sugar, sherry, cinnamon, lemon zest. Sweet, candied fruits in onset, brown sugar or candi syrup sweetness, banana and orange peel, after which a thick but soft and mellow, deep chocolatey maltiness unfolds, smooth and velvety, a bit more powdery in the finish, with gentle, mouth-filling, coffee-like roasted bitterness, creamy malt sweetness, a lemony sourish touch and peppery hop touch; the alcohol remains well hidden. Indeed this has a Belgian yeast touch to it, reminded me a bit of Struises Black Albert. Well done.

12 oz bottle from BOTW (Rochester), served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. 
App.: Deep mahogany with a fair orange-tan head.
 
Aroma: Starts with a tangy funk of infection (dang), dark-roasted malt notes, a little burnt malt, hints of molasses, mainly infection...a shame.
 
Palate: Medium+ body with very full, silky carbonation.
 
Flav.: More of the true beer character with less infection, dark roasted malt, milk chocolate, faint molasses, dark treacle, brown sugar, still has a nasty backdrop; dry with moderate bitterness, slightly tangy, with a long, dark-roasted malt finish.

Seems like it would be good if not infected. Thats too bad.
Bottle share. Hazy dark brown. Aroma of Belgian yeast, chocolate, coffee, prunes. Taste is bittersweet. Creamy smooth dry finish.

750 ml bottle. Pours a slightly orange black with a resilient, pale beige to white head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, wood, herbs and pine tree. Flavor is sweet chocolate, candy, black licorice and cocoa. Finish is a tad bit tart and lemony. Unexpected!. Rather dry. Light to medium body, average carbonation.

Bottle. Dark cola brown, soapy tan head. Roasted barley aroma with dark fruit/raisin. The taste adds Belgian yeast notes and licorice. Smooth drinkable palate with low carb. Very tasty. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2014 I hate my tablet. How can my rating not have been saved? *Updated (slightly inebriated) Rating*. Purchased in town earlier today. $7.99 for the 750 mL bottle. (As a sidenote, astonishment exists to such a degree that I havent Ratebeer-classified this specific Foreign Stout before entering it in the database now. How couldnt I? Get buzzed fast, I guess...for the majority of 1.3 years? Fuck.) To oversized snifter, it pours a samey mahogany/rust brown-tinted charcoal (black, dipshit), with which a watered-down khaki head 1 finger in length stood. Aromas of pipe tobacco, candied sugar, dried lavender, blue agave syrup, roasted bartlett pears, Belgian yeast (no shit, dumbass), topsoil, cognac heat, and the faintest hint of fresh chopped mint. Tastes the same with the addition of black tea, graham crackers, noble hops, white  chocolate, and avocados. A tinge, I guess you could say, of "hospitable earthiness", unripe blueberries, and cooking mushrooms (shiitake, silan, etc.), too, experienced at swallow. Undeniably fruitier than I was expecting.
Enjoyable. Black red with tan head. Aroma is sweet candied cherry. Taste adds a smokey bitterness. Not great, but good.

BOD 156/14. Pours almost black with a quite a bit of dark ruby. Normal head with above normal lacing and retention. Light nose of chocolate, Belgian yeast, candi sugar and hints of dark fruit and roast. Medium bodied with a nice slick texture that hints at creaminess. Above normal carbonation with effervescence in the middle and finish. The excellent flavor profile is of reasonable intensity, quite complex and exceptionally balanced. It begins with semisweet dark chocolate over a very mild roast character. As the effervescent middle begins, the chocolate fades to candi sugar sweetness and more of the roast character is noted. As this sweetness fades, dark fruit notes come to the forefront. The finish is smooth, but has dry characteristics, and a bit of hop flavor and bitterness in addition to hints of coffee. A slight dark chocolate note lingers. The alcohol (7.5%) is totally hidden.

Pours a dark brown to almost black with a small foamy tan head. Aroma is roasted coffee, chocolate, and belgian yeast strands. Taste of espresso, dark chocolate, yeast, and a hint of black licorice. I poured a 12oz bottle into a chalice. There was no discernible freshness date.

Appearance: Dark brown/black opaque body. Forms a small, eggshell, soapy head which mostly dissipates and leaves little lacing on the glass. 

Smell: Classic stout aroma plus a classic Belgian yeast aroma. Strange but interesting.

Taste: I should disclaim this review by mentioning that I have had this beer before on tap and it was pretty amazing. Id never seen it in bottles until recently, so I grabbed one when I had the chance. I have to say Im pretty disappointed by the difference between the tap and bottle versions. Even though its been a while between decantation, the memory of that beer being amazing stayed fresh. Allagash Black in the bottle isnt so much a good or bad beer as it is weird. The authentic Belgian yeast strain really makes itself known, but so does the classic strong stout base and the two conflict. 

The palate begins rather mild with a general stout flavor. Light chocolate and coffee notes are noticeable, though they amplify greatly at the apex. Theres a strong dry bitterness of burnt coffee, dark chocolate and Belgian yeast spiciness. As it finishes the Belgian yeast becomes much more prominent, imparting slight banana and potpourri flavors, but theres still noticeable chocolate and coffee as well. When all these notes collide they create for a strange, almost fish-like taste, leaving an aftertaste of coffee. Though at no point is this palate repulsive, its just an eyebrow-raiser. 

Drinkability: Belgian beers are known for being zesty and effervescent, and while thats true of Allagash Black, its still a remarkably drinker-friendly palate. A mouthfeel thats on the thinner side with no alcohol presence at all. The aftertaste is slightly dry and bitter, but is akin to coffee so its easily tolerable. The 7.5% ABV seems right on point, if not a tad high, but I doubt many drinkers will find it challenging to drink in large quantities.

Medium body with a high level of carbonation and a sweet bubbly mouthfeel. This one isnt bad, it actually grew on me through the glass, but Im not sure Id grab it again.

Bottle from Total Wines, Sterling VA. Near black and opaque with a decent, off-white head. Aroma of Belgian yeasts, plain chocolate and roasted malts. Flavour had some dark fruit sweetness, porridge oats, more chocolate and black coffee notes, leading to a dryish finish. Very enjoyable.

Tap. Pours clear ruby black with a small tan head and decent lacing. Aroma is yeast, roasted malt, coffee, tobacco. Flavor its about the same, medium sweet, a bit funky, a bit of coffee bitterness. Light body, a bit creamy. Not very stouty. Warming finish.
Oak sharp on the nose. Some espresso, and roasted malt. Chocolate and coffee taste. As well as oak, wheat, toffee, roasted malt. Persistent thick off-white head throughout the session. A delight!
Bottle. Pours dark with some nice roasted malt aromas. Flavor is roasted malts and chocolate. I was expecting (and hoping for) something thicker but a nice beer overall.

Black pour, thin caramel head.. aromas of roasted malts, oatmeal.  Flavors of chocolate and coffee but leans more towards the coffee and roasted notes.  Good beer but felt like somethjng was missing...

Black pour with big Ta head. Nose is roasty malts,funk, cloves, tobacco?. Full bodied semisweet roasted malts, tobacco cloves other spices. Mellow yet spicy ending. Good texture. Nice beer for winter.

Black pour....a bit of cloudy dark brown at the bottom.  Bottle fermentation left some sediment.  Toasted malt.  Some oatmeal flavor.  A hint of Belgian style yeast, but not too much wang.   Reminds me of unibroue la fin du Monde, but a little smoother for better or worse.  Foamy head that lasts.

Clear black with a touch of brown at the edges. Small tan head reduces fast to a partial coat, but theres enough carbonation to produce some lacing. 

A fruity, yeasty aroma thats more like a hefeweizen than expected. Flavor is a cross between a Belgian PA and a wheat beer. It has a relatively high hop/malt ratio for style. Spicy from both the yeast and more subtle hops. 
Medium body with somewhat lively carbonation.

O: an interesting and well balanced ale.
Nice aroma of Belgian yeast. tastes of Belgian yeast and sweet malt. Black with an off white head.

Bottle on Amtrak Train 506 between Portland and Seattle (from Binnys South Loop) 08/11/12.
Mid black with a big frothy tan head that reatains well.
Nose comprises Belgian yeast esters, dark fruits, touch of soap, light mineral tones.
Tastes of chocolate, dates, prunes, figs, roasted malts, Belgian yeast strains.
Medium bodied with soft carbonation.
Decent stuff!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Draft at two stones pub. Pours black with a thin khaki head. Nice malty goodness on the nose. Lots of molasses on the tongue. Very sweet but not cloying. Solid!

Thanks to TheHopster. Bottle poured into Chimay glass, cola color with thin tan head, notes of caramel, chocolate, Belgian yeast, nice play between malt and hops, very enjoyable

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle marked 2222.  Nose is dark roast, dry with a little chocolate, many, that is ridiculously joyous roast in the nose, fresh coffee with plenty of Maillard, a little chicory.  Dark brown-black with a hint of light shining through and a creamy, foamy light brown head.  Taste is sweeter than expected, not cloying or even sugary, but that candis is front and center and attacks from the first sip.  Airy with good maintenance of the roast but the Belgian yeast and candis move it to the bg.  Just a hint of fruit, and the alcohol is masterfully hidden.  Smooth and silken medium body, quenching and just super repeatable -- much prefer this Black to their White.

A 12 oz. bottle decants a dark brown ale with a smallish, quickly falling dark tan head.  The aroma on this beer quickly reveals the advertised roasted malt, chocolate and coffee notes, but I also picked up some grassy hops and alcohol in the nose as the beer approaches room temperature.  This stout drinks smooth start to finish.  Palate entry is minimally sweet with the anticipated dark malt, chocolate and coffee flavors peeking through some surprisingly lively carbonation.  Bottle fermentation amplifies the dry finish and higher ABV.  Very good.

(12-oz bottle)   A nice combination of roasted malts with Belgian yeast.  Sophisticated flavor without intensity.  Notes of dark chocolate and roasted coffee without overwhelming the quality of malt blends and yeast.  Very smooth palate.  A nice winter choice.
Bottle->snifter.  Deep brown, light head.  Aroma is 5:00am at the bar - smoke, char, coffee, wet funk. Taste is roasted malt over yeast.  Just OK.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2013 Draft. Black pour with a thin foamy tan head. Not much aroma but a lot of dark flavors. Unsweetened chocolate. Charcoal campfire burnt marshmallows. Black coffee. Vinyl. No red fruit. Feels like the Allagash White burnt to cinders. Nice, but feels a bit too thin.
Appearance is medium brown head with deep brown. Aroma is a sweet malt. Taste is a slightly toasted malt, but not enough punch. Overall just ok.

12oz bottle. Pours a dark brown with thin, espresso-cream colored head. Nose is yeasty and some roasted malt. Mouth is medium bodied, Belgian yeasts (think Saison), coffee notes and malt. Read a few reviews on here, so maybe its just me, but I really thought this one was only mediocre.

Aroma is very faint yeast, biscuit, and roasted caramel. Blackish magenta in appearance with a thin rim of foam. Well carbonated with flavors of dark roasted barley, caramel, thin molasses, yeast and some cocoa. Not as intense and heavy as I had anticipated. Overall, its well done with a tad bit of booze on the end. Much more light bodied and easy going than anticipated. Id give this a B+ rating.

Pours a dark reddish brown transparent colour with noticeable cloudiness from the bottle conditioning. Smell is yeasty, toasted malt, Coco. Taste is slight bitterness with roasted malt up front slight booze taste in the middle finishing with chocolate.

Pours a clear dark brown color with decent off white head that dissipates quickly and leaves little lace. Smells of roasted coffee and some yeast on the nose. Taste is yeast up front with some roast coffee and then a transition into booze then some chocolate and hoppiness on the finish. Good complexion and mouth feel.

I am not a big stout fan and I thought Alagash may have a take on it that would empress me. Plus I only paid $6 at Costco. Its good. Doesnt really compare to there better beers. Bitter coffee, thin, not a lot of Belgium going on here.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle thanks to Lukaduke. Poured a very dark, dense black with a thick, beige head of foam with good retention. The aroma has notes of very dark, bitter chocolate, roasted nuts, some wood, and some marshmallow. That marshmallow really kicks this beer up a little for me. The taste is some more bitter sweet super dark chocolate with some walnut hulls drying it out and allowing for some sweetness to peak through toward the finish. Thick, chewy mouthfeel. Very viscous. This beer is very good. Thanks for the hookup Luke!

Poured from a 12 oz bottle shared at home.  pors a deep cola brown with a thick beige head with lots of lacing.  Somewhat sour yeast and malt aroma.  Notes of dark sour cherries with light brown sugar.  Slightly metallic bitter finish.

I am a huge fan of the Black. It has delicious roast and maltiness. The taste is slick and smooth. I found it pairs really well with a cigar or pipe. I have had it numerous times, and aging for a few months definitely does takes some of the roast out and makes it even better IMO.

Belgian Stout/Strong Dark Ale 7.5%.  Dark brown, clear, like root beer or a strong coffee color and taste.  Beautiful balance malt-roasted-hop, bitter but not too much. Long aftertaste, balanced. Brewer talks of chocolate and toast. Malty character. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Initial aromas of citrus peal, earth and grass.  Dark, almost black body with a short lived head.  Semi sweet chocolate flavors with earth and floral notes.  Medium in body.  And interesting brew.

Reviewed 9/29. About 7 oz poured into a Duvel tulip.

A: Pours a dark brown color that betrays a hint of transparency even in this dark environment. The head is a one finger light khaki color that fades to a thin collar relatively quickly. Theres a hint of spotty lacing on the glass.

S: Rather estery, especially with pear and apple. I have to dig around to notice the chocolate and roast, but its there. Another taste noticed a touch of sourness.

T: At first, its a bit roasty and chocolaty, but the finish betrays its Belgian roots with fruity apple esters. The faint touch of sourness on the aroma comes through on the general flavor, which I really appreciate. It really takes a few sips to appreciate everything going on in the profile, but once that happens, one can really appreciate the complexity and nuance within this.

M: A little bit on the heavy side, but with a great finishing dryness and moderate carbonation.

O: The first sip doesnt wow me, but it rewards a patient palate with solid complexity. Id definitely have this one again.

Bottle. Pours a thinner almost-black color with very little head. Lots of roasted flavors in the nose. Some nice roasted malty flavors to this, though it has an underlying subtle sweetness to it that comes from the yeast. That sweetness is the only aspect I dont like.

On tap at Victory Lane.

A: Pitch black with a thin dense head.

S: Weak, mostly chalky banana yeast.

T: Dark chocolate, chalky yeast, and a medicinal dark fruit finish.

M: Thick body light carbonation.

O: Goof but it meshes weird.

12 oz. bottle from Total Wine in Chesapeake, VA.  Dark brown cola-like pour with a frothy khaki head.  Aroma of dark chocolate and roasted coffee.  Taste of dark roasted malts that give a smoky flavor, burnt espresso, and bitter chocolate.  A bit of the smokiness lingers on the palate.  Nicely done.
Great flavored beer. A little off on the hops.  Like a Guiness foreign extra stout with more flavor. 32 ounce growler. Clemson, SC Bountyland.

Great Belgian style stout. Has the high end Belgian finish from the triple and quadruple but in a dark roasted beer. Excellent. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Raisins, a little smoke, and grass nose. Clear brown, which is odd given the name, thick tan head, good lacing. Rich raisin and coffee flavor. Grassy overtones. Medium body.
Deep brown with light tan head.  Aroma of dark fruit.  Taste is candy sugar, Belgian yeast, highly carbed with good body.

Pours black with a nice one finger off white, light brown head. Aroma is roasted, chocolate, dont really get the belgian yeast? Maybe mmy nose is off today? Taste is creamy with nice maltiness, chocolate, roast, coffee some hints of dark fruits in there. In the taste I get the belgian yeast. All in all a nice stout.

Draught at Ginger Man, NYC. Black beer with a nice lasting beige head. Licorice aroma, chocolate, cocoa powder, coffee, vinous, figs, some plums, raisins, roasted, some soot. Vinous chocolate flavor, cocoa powder, figs, raisins, dades, soot, smoked notes, hop notes, some iron, but most of all this is a sweet and still very pleasant beer.

Cloudy dark brown with appreciable lacing.  A lovely sweet roasty coffee caramel aroma.   Flavor is roasty with a faint backround of dark fruit.  Just a bit of hoppiness in the aftertaste.  A lovely smooth drinkable beer,

I saw the description "belgian style stout" on the label and had high hopes.  I found this beer very much not a stout.  Its not even a porter.  Id consider it more of a black ale.  Its got a bit of malty sweetness in a belgian ale style but a stout it is not.  If youre looking for a big bold stout this isnt it.  I was disappointed.
Dark brown color with a big tan head. Aroma of roasted malts and chocolate. Taste is medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, drinkable with a roasty finish.
Draft at winners circle. Pours black with a small head that dissipates quickly. Aroma had some chocolate with a good bit of roast. Taste is solid on coffee and pretty bitter.

Virginia Trip  bottle 750 ml
Aroma pleasant , rich dark character. Well blended in alcohol. Good.7+
 Appearance   brown-black with medium plus top. Presentable appearance.
Flavor and Palate : Clean, strong with mature character. Solid body with perhaps slight unnecessary metallic hints. Quiet drinkable.

750ml bottle. Cellared for about 10 months. A little ruby around the edges, otherwise very dark, big tan head. Aroma is bakers chocolate, with some hints of fruity and earthy. Taste is dark chocolate with some earthy bitterness on the back of the palate. Little bit of roasted coffee and Belgian yeast. Palate is very smooth and has a good body. Overall, a very nice stout.
Pours a nice dark brown almost black. Has a nice roasted coffee, raisin, malt taste. Purchased it in a growler from holiday. Its a a little  pricey but very good.
Very silk flavor with bits of chocolate and roasted malt in the flavor. Did even taste a hint of wheat and oats on the finish. A really nice and unique beer had it in a bottle

750 ml bottle, pours opaque black w/ fluffy taupe head, aroma is chocolate, light tobacco and some esters, silky malt sweet and round with no detectable roast, finishes dry and relatively clean, lively carbonation, not what I expected, but tasty all the same

Such a nice beer!  Pours inky black with a small off white head.  Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate and belgian yeast.  Taste is quite similar to how it smells.  Deep roasted malts, quite complex and layered, drying out the palate is the belgian yeast and to sweeten the pot is the dark chocolate notes.  Great beer.

Bottle shared at tasting from Deanso, 2008 vintage.  Pours black with a small tan head.  Aroma is fairly light, cocoa and dark fruit.  Flavour is cocoa up front with dark fruit and roasted malt soft medium sweetness and light bitter.  Full bodied with soft carbonation.

66cl bottle from the US aged in my beer cellar.
Decent creamy tan head.  Clear dark pour.  Smoky/alcohol/port notes.  very smooth.  The ageing worked well

Poured from the bottle into a tulip glass. Pours a tan head that is nice and full.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, roasted malt very similar to a regular stout. Taste is chocolate, coffee, sweet roasted malt. Mouthfeel overall is full, maybe acidic?. Overall a great stout, not really sure what makes this a Belgian stout though.

Bottle (750 ml). Dark brown (almost black) with a medium light brown head and some lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and acidic notes. Flavor are about the same. Medium body. Not a bad foreign stout but theres too much acidity.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours black with low beige head. Nice lacing. Aroma is of roasted malt, sligth acidity. Taste is of roasted malt, sweetness, acidity. Full bodied. Overall: good balance. Nothing exceptionnal, but a worthy beer.
A solid allagash offering. Nice creamy choclate malts blend with the dark fruity belgian yeast for a nice one.

Bottle
Appearance - Deep brown, frothy head
Aroma - Chocolate, coffee, grassy hops
Taste - Mellow chocolate, roasted malts, dark chocolate finish

This was a great beer, lots of chocolate and coffee in the body and aroma - also full of yeast and other hints of Belgian influences. Very drinkable too.

Thanks Chipalsa for bringin this one over. Nose is sweet with a yeasty note, some spice, roast, chocolate, and a triple like fruity aroma. Pour is nice and dark with a light tan head. Taste follows the nose with a good amount of chocolate and spice with a touch of roast and fruity flavors. Good. This is a very interesting beer, though, with tons of influences from both styles - stout and belgian. Nice.
Love the chocolate notes and hint of roasted coffee. Very good taste, atoms, appearance

On draught. Pours dark, dark brown but not quite black with a big tan head. Aroma of yeast backed by big, toasty malt and roasted coffee. Taste matches. Pleasing balance between belgian candi sweetness and coffee, toffee, chocolatey malt. Very smooth and an easy drink.

Bottle thx to Jf and Jess. A: roasty, chocolate, caramel. App: pitch black with white head. T/p: full body with sweet and short finish. Silky texture, high carbonation. O:Amazingly good. Love the equilibrium simply superb.
Smooth tasting beer, not bitter, good hints of chocolate and coffee, very good taste.

From a 750ml bottle into a brandy glass.  Batch #29 (I think).  The cork FIRED off of this one!  Pissed the wife of royally.  Pours a moderately dark (but not black) ()()()())( colour.  Aroma of coffee and wine.  Inch and a half of dark white (call it eggshell) head and no lacing.  Mouthfeel is moderate and actually light for a stout.  Flavours of coffee, cinnamon, raisins and charcoal.  Overall, an OK beer but plenty of ones that are better.  Wont be buying this again.

Black pour and a big off white head. Big coco coffee aroma. Super smooth silky mouth feel. Full bodied with well balanced coffee and chocolate flavors. Slightly sweet no bitter 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught.
Pitch black, beige head.
Rich, roasted, malty aroma, hops, coffee, tobacco, candied sugar.
Semi-sweet, full body, medium bitterness, creamy CO2.
Malty, roasted, creamy taste, chocolate, coffee, yeast, tobacco, plum, ashes, smoke.
Long, rich, dry finish.
(2012-05-03)

Allagash black. Bottle pours black cola tinge light light tan cola head and well laced. Aromas of roast coffee bean sweet dark toffee caramel Light medium body, medium, high zesty carbonation with a generous piney bitterness. Lingering coffee, roast flavors a touch light on the body for all the roast with vanilla smoke wood rounding out the finish.

Just opened bottle, im expecting a very sweet very full bodied stout.  The color seems as black as the name and label with virtually no head....sad... The aroma smells like coffee and a sweet smell.  Both very faint. The taste is almost as i thought.  Sweet medium/full body.  Must use same yeast as the other allagash beer that i had i forget the name.  But it has an identical taste.  No hoppy flavor no vanilla or chocolate or coffee for that matter as in most other stouts.  For a belgian stout i say they did a fairly decent job.  Worth a buy at least once.

More carbonated and lighter body than expected. Subtle aroma. Creamy tan head. No lacing. Not my favorite stout but ok.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
light aroma coffee, malt, chocolate. pours black beige head. taste coffee, chocolate and malts slightly bitter, lively on palate and smooth. finish coffee, chocolate very good stout

Tap. Pours opaque black with thick, creamy beige head; good retention and lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, figs and other dark fruit, faint earthy hops, and light toffee. Flavor is malt forward with good supporting hops and fruit esters; dry finish. Medium body, carbonation, and finish.

At Tylers. Good aroma, sweet roasty. Roasty malt, with  sweet  streak. Orangy brown color, good head, minor lace. Roasty sweet flavor. Medium body, creamy smooth mouthfeel. Dry sweet finish. Tasty. I like the play with yeast and malt, just enough of a change from the foreign stout  to distinguish itself.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text:
On tap at Quarry House Tavern in Silver Spring, MD.  Poured into a tulip glass. 

Opaque, near black with a one-finger tan head that settled quickly. Good lacing.

Aroma of dark fruit, molasses, dates, roasted malt and yeast.  

Taste of dark, roasted malt, molasses, licorice, cherry and dark fruit. 

Medium plus body with average carbonation and an inviting mouthfeel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours in between black and deep dark red with a khaki head. Smell is a bit fruity, belgium yeast, and a bit of roast. Taste is very roasty, almost like an imperial porter, bit of a burning on the tail end. Red fruit present, but ash and bitter coffee dominates, the Belgium sweetness doesnt come through in the flavor. Slightly disappointing.

This is a beauty! Pours nearly pitch black with a very creamy coloured head that sticks around for awhile. Some lacing in glass. Nose is dark fruit with maybe a small hint of coffee. Up front same idea, prunes, maybe some lighter plums. Middle and back are maltier, with coffee and maybe a hint of dark chocolate. Light carbonation and a pretty smooth feel in the mouth. Great beer!

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2012 Draft at Pony with Streets and BRendan. Pours a deep black with light reddish hue. Aroma is sweet roast, chocolate, and light coffee. Mouthfeel is thin with notes of sweet roast and light chocolate.  Tasted like an imperial porter.

Copper in color with an off-white head.  Sweet caramel and toffee notes with a bit more in the way of roast and chocolate than I usually expect in a quad.  Still, decently sweet.  The roast and slight coffee flavors are a bit strange, but they work, I suppose.  A touch of chocolate along with dark fruit and the usual toffee, caramel, and brown sugar notes.

Pours dark clear brown with a thin head.  Aroma is marshmallows, chocolate, some belgian esters.  Taste is chocolate, some red fruit, roasty coffee, caramel, yeast esters.  Body is medium, silky, active carbonation, dry roasty caramel finish.  Overall, delicious.

750ml corked bottle pours almost black in color with a finger of light beige head that leaves some thin spotty lacing.  Aroma is roasted malts with chocolate and hints of yeast and hops.  Taste is roasted malt and mild hop bitterness balanced nicely with a chocolate and caramel malty sweetness.  Light to medium body which is uncharacteristic of this style and light carbonation.  Overall, this is quite a good stout and worthy of a sampling.
Nice stout, slightly sweet on the palate. Syomewhat hoppy. Nice smithh mouth feel. Very little head, slight lacing. Not a bad beer, but only once on the list

Draught at Rattl N Hum, NYC Black body. Aroma of heavily roasted coffee with an accent of (sigarette?) smoke: intense and complex, but because of the sigarette smoke (surely not of the pub) it leaves me puzzled what to think of it; it disturbes me somehow. Flavour is not very impressive. Quite lightly bodied.
