Dark ruby color, steady beige head. Fruity, maybe even a bit citrusy nose, weak aroma. Medium-bodied. Suprisingly flavor is quite different than aroma: mostly black coffee with light sweet-fruity hints. Palate is quite watery for this ABV.

Poured into a goblet. No head, only a faint covering, dark amber to brown colored. Bubbles visible.

Smells spicy, molasses, black licorice, yeasty and roasted malt.

Bold and rich flavor. Roasted malt, some sweetness at the beginning, bready, lots of burnt malt at the end. Complex profile and perfectly put together.

Light and "fluffy" texture. Low carbonation.

Incredible! Just a bit more on the appearance and this is near perfect.

Draught at Milltown.  Pours a soft stained wood brown with two fingers creamy sandy tan head.  Nose is roasty and estery with lots of char and some burnt toast.  Nice balance of yeast esters and roasty black malt.  Dry and light bodied.

750ml bottle pours a very dark brown with a light tan head and good lacing.  Aroma is more subdued than I expected, with licorice, chocolate, roasted maltsand a hint of fruits.  Full bodied texture with a creamy mouthfeel.  Well carbonated.  Taste is on the bitter side at first, but the roasted malts come out in the finish.  Im glad to have tried it, but dont know when or if Ill try it again.

From Beerlicious iphone app:  I smell Corriander and banana.  Its Black and clear with a minimal tan head.  Starts out with light sourness and finish that way along with some medium bitterness.  Medium body with a creamy oily texture.
Bottle at Mondial de la Biere, Strasbourg 2011. Pours dark brown with a tanned head. Sweet with aromas of caramel and hints of sweet liquorish. Spicy. Medium bodied. Medium carbonation. Spicy finish.

On tap: Pasture.  Appearance: black, frothy whitish tan head. Aroma: roasted malt, faint chocolate, not strong aroma at all. Taste: roasted malty goodness, makes up for lack of aroma, licorice, some mocha coffee, nice hoppyish finish. Mouthfeel: creamy, thickish body. Overall: really delicious!  One of the best of the style for me so far. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012.02.16 - 750ml bottle in tulip glass, "Batch# 33".  Despite the name it pours more dark brown than black.  Light 1/2" head active with small bubbles recedes quickly, light lacing.  Aroma is a bit subdued for a stout.  Taste is good and also a bit subdued.  Mostly a roasty chocolate malt taste as expected of stouts.  Mouthfeel is pretty light.  If you want a stout but not a really heavy one, this might be a good candidate.

My first belgian stout, light black pour with a good amount of head and carbonation. Yeasty, fruity, roasted aroma.  I normally expect more aroma from a stout, but it seemed somewhat muted.  chocolate, coffee, yeasty taste, a lot lighter than expected.  Great overall beer, but not sure if I would go back to it.

Pours black with a dense 1/2" head. Light aroma of chocolate malt and hops. Medium to full bodied with tastes that mirror the aroma. Palate is a bit astringent from carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The aroma is muted, but has hints of coffee, chocolate, lemon, yeast. Medium carbonation, dry and roasty in the middle, yeasty, with a nicely balanced finish, which has a welcome citrusy acidity from the hops. Kind of one dimensional, I was expecting a bit more.

Allagash Black pours a almost black color with ruby red highlights.  Very small amount of head is poured with minimal lacing.  This beer is categorized as a Belgian Strong  Dark Ale on BA.  Allagash calls it a Belgian Style stout.  But honestly by the looks of it you could think this is a stout. 

First thing I picked up off this brew is coffee.  Followed up by dark roasted malt.  Slight chocolate presence mixed in with an even smaller candi sugar presence.  Decent aroma.

Coffee backs off a bit here and meshes well with the sweetness of the chocolate. Some smoked, charred malt character and a yeasty taste can be tasted in the background.  Not huge but if I didnt know it I would think this is a 100% an American Stout.  Either my palette isnt trained well enough yet or Im losing it in my old age. 

Goes down easy enough.  Low carbonation.  Medium bodied.

Pours basically a black color with a medium sized tight off white head that leaves lots of lacing on the glass. 

The aroma is fruity and roasty with some mild licorice, but generally this beer is pretty faint smelling all around, its also kind of one noted, its a nice note but it doesnt make for very exciting smelling beer. 

The flavor makes up for where the aroma lacks. The beer is fairly bitter with a good licorice flavor that builds as the beer warms. The beer is dry, roasty and mildly spicy. Everything in the aroma works pretty darned harmoniously too.
Sweet, milky, chocolatey. Smooth. Wheat undertones. Not too heavy, but velvety.

Beau liquide noir opaque chapeauté par une belle mousse beige. Nez très intéressant et complexe. On y retrouve un mélange bien exécuté entre une belge et une stout impériale, cest-à-dire dépices, de caramel et de grains torréfiés. Le goût est très similaire aux arômes. On goûte en plus une touche de mélasse et de café espresso. Très belle surprise. (143-010112)

From notes: Batch #28.  Pours ink-black with a small, light tan head.  Aroma of chocolate mixed with coffee.  Slightly thick, with a nice depth.  Roasty flavor, mixed with coffee.  As it warms a bit, yeasty and earthy notes come forward.

Bottle, pours light black (if thats possible?), light tan head. Nose is bitter coffee, dark chocolate, slight funkiness from the Belgian yeast. Taste is nowhere near as sweet as some other foreign stouts. Nice roasted bitterness, lively, champagne-like mouthfeel. Interesting, and very good.

On Draft at Ballydoyle Bloomingdale.  This beer is great, they bill it is a belgian style stout, not sure if that is what i would call it.  Dark black in color, yet very clear.  It drinks a lot lighter than i was expecting.  Nice head out of the draft and into an allagash glass.  I get some of the chocolate and roasted notes, very hard to describe, but it is the best beer i have had this year so far for sure.
#1161 draught; nose is umami, mediumsweet malt, weak caramel, coffee whiff, feel is medium, carb is medium, taste is soursweet malt, coffee, weak cough syrup, later cane sugar, sweet plum finish
From the tap poured a black color with a good amount of head.  Light toasted malty flavor with a quick finish.

Bottle.  Pours a deep black with a slight reddish tinge and a thick head that lingers.  This is a very mellow stout without biting flavors or bitterness.  A mild roasted malt flavor comes through with a slight alcohol burn in the aftertaste.  It is very smooth and you dont notice the high alcohol content when you are drinking it, so it sneaks up on you.  A pretty good stout overall.

As the title reads, this beer pours black with a nice tan head. Aromas are strong roasted malts, dark chocolate, notes of coffee. Flavor is slight coffee with the roasted malts taking over, bits of chocolate in the background. The sweet is balanced nicely with the bitterness of the coffee notes. Very smooth beer, goes down dangerously smooth for a 7.5%.
From a tap, chocolate, coffee, roasty,minimal white head,medium body,above average carbonated.

750 bottle corked & caged - 

Its been awhile since Ive had an Allagash product, as I always think they are incredibly overpriced for such a mostly average product. But this was a great, great beer. Tons of roasted malts, lots of choco-mocha flavors. Almost dessert like with the toffee, chocolate, coffee flavors. Aroma was nearly matching the aroma, but some really nice smokey aromas coming out. Very well attenuated and basically nails the FES style. Great beer.

Bottle, batch #29. Pours a very dark ruby red with a white head. Smells sweet with roasted malt. Tastes a fruity sweet with some bitter roasted malt. Perhaps vanilla and cherry, rounded out with a hint of peat. Medium bodied. Medium active carbonation. Finishes slightly tart. Very tasty.

Bottle. Pours very dark brown with a medium light tan head. The aroma is dark fruit, chocolate, sweet roasted malt, sweet tobacco and light coffee. The flavour is sweet and roasted with notes of dark chocolate and dark ripe fruit. Very delicious!

Best of the tasting as far as I can tell, tho I did rate some from that tasting better. From draft, I thought this was a black IPA but the rep said it was a dark belgian (seems right for Allagash). Medium heavy body with caramel, coffee, chocolate, roasted influences. Flower and herb hops notes. Kinda smoky in a way. Very well done and a great winter warmer at 7.5%
Poured from the corkEd bottle. Has a silky head. Aroma is of raspberries. Flavor is interesting. Lots of roasted malts are evident. Overall a very interesting beer.

Soft carbonation block head biege colour pitch black pour thick in viscosity aromas rich chocolate  caramel vanilladark fruits raisin prune liquorice expresso coffee flavours dry cocoa rich chocolate liquorice prune raisin mild medium bitter vanilla smoothness oily touch finish rich malts dark fruits a dry taste good bitter that lastsvery enjoyable

Got a 750 ml corked and caged bottle. Poured into a Chimay goblet. Dark brown but somewhat translucent compared to say an imperial stout. Beautiful off white head that left some lacing on the glass. Aroma was of milk chocolate, yeast, and slight hops. Taste was full of roasted malts, chocolate malts, and spicy belgian yeast. Mouth feel was a little bit thin but the velvety carbonation made up for it. Very enjoyable and very easy to drink.
Black pour, minimal head. Chocolate, roast and fruit in aroma. Chocolate, cocoa and yeast in flavor. Medium thick.

batch 32 Cola pour, black body, small tan head. Aroma of milk, coca, yeast, roast, and dark fruit. Burnt, roasted malts in the flavor, some chocolate, and dark fruit on the finish. Silky mouthfeel with mellow carbonation and some alcohol warming.
On tap at the Bridge View tavern. Nice black as coal pour with a thin head. Toasty roasty chocholety goodness with a bold sweet palat! Wow. Thats all I have to say. Enjoy!

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours a solid black with a dissipating off-white head. Aroma of roasted wood, booze and chocolate. Flavour of roasted wood, nuts, coffee / espresso, and chocolate. Palate is full-bodied and roasty. Nice.

Pint on tap pours black with a reddish brown head.  Aromas of coffee roasted malt a bit of chocolate nib and a bit of dough.  Flavors of roasted malts some bitter chocolate and just a hint if mocha. Body is great and full very creamy and smooth. Leaves a good after taste not to much coffee.

Bottle pour thanks to Steve, aroma is dark black with off white head, aroma has some red fruit, banana, biscuit, spice, hints of metallic, roast and chocolate.  Taste is nice roast, chocolate, fruity pear, spice, some banana, finishes with that hint of metal, slightly bitter as well.

750ml bottle poured into glass. All for myself in celebration of my new car. Ive been holding onto this bottle for about a year, no real reason but it stood the test of time. Good chocolate and vanilla flavor, both in the aroma and flavor. Was a great treat to have.
Pours deep brown with an off-white head. Aroma consists of oats and honey, with hints of coffee. Very unique and delicious beer, although it could be a lot thicker in my opinion.

Draught at Beachwood BBQ.  
Barely translucent of dark, red light.  Persistent sandy head and sticky, coating, covering lacing.
Aroma is of wood, licorice, and root beer.
Taste is mildly salty and red-wine sweet (but not vinous as I dont like vinous, and I like this beer) most like mild root beer.
Palate is so smooth almost to a point of numbness.
A very good beer.

Draft at Great Lost Bear in Portland.  Roasty, lightly sweet aroma, malty with suggestions of oatmeal and wheat, some molasses, dark chocolate, burnt sugar, faint yeast esters, some toasted/burnt grain notes as well.  Solid ebony color, head is very slight with spidery lace.  Roasty, sweet, multi-grain flavor profile, more dark molasses, lightly charred grains and dark sugary sweetness, bitterness is there right away to balance and seems to be generated much more from the roasted malt than from any hop additions.  Finishes with hints of cocoa and chocolate.  Low degree of effervescence, mouthfeel is quite thick and heavy, body is of course full.  Nicely flavorful.

750mL bottle, split 3 ways, pours black with a small beige head. Aroma of Belgian yeast, candied sugar, some vanilla and chocolate. Flavour of Belgian yeast, vanilla, spices and chocolate. Weird spices give me mixed feelings on this. A solid off-kilter stout, but nothing more.

Bottle at Limoncello in West Chester.  Pours a black color with a thinnish off white head that settles to bubbles that rim the edge of the glass.  Appearance reminds you of a belgian ale.  Tastes like a cross between a stout and a brown ale.  Very drinkable and reasonable alcohol content that doesnt overpower.  Nice after dinner beer.

On tap at Haymarket. Pours dark brownish black with tan head. Aromas of chocolate, roasted malts, and dark fruits. Flavors of roasted malts, yeasty dough, chocolate, some fruit and spices mixed in as well. Mouthfeel was a little thin, but this was still enjoyable.

750ml bottle in a snifter.  Pours black with a thick, lacy, light tan head.  Aroma of roasted and some caramel malts, spicy yeast, a little chocolate, and light hops.  Flavor could be more roasted, but its a lot for a stout like this.  The beer is silky in texture, with a lot of carbonation.  A really good beer.

GABF 2011.  Black pour with some coppery brown highlights, under a light beige head. Rich chocolaty roasty aroma with some toffee and black licorice backing up. Big palate but not overwhelming. Roasted chocolate malts, chewy roasted cereal grains, some licorice, and a dryish astringent finish. Not a perfect stout, but ok.

Bottle. Black with a large light tan head. Modest aroma of dough, pears, berries, mocha. Very silky mouthfeel. Sweet with mocha, light roasted malt, dough, pears, some mild spices. Roasted notes creep up a little along with some licorice. Fullish flavoured - although it lacks depth in the roasted department - but pleasantly light-textured. Unusual and rather stylish.

The aroma and apperance is expected and the palate is underwhelming.  The roasted malts give this beer the thrust it needs to drive it home as one to remember.  I drank it with the complamentory oatmeal with brown sugar and it was fine.

4/10/2011 on tap @ Rattle n Hum, NYC (2011-515)
Clear dark ruby red to brown beer, small dark brown sediment floating around, small beige head, unstable and non adhesive. Aroma: dry, smoke and ashes, dark chocolate and coffee, some dark caramel. MF: very little carbon, full body, oily texture, very thick. Taste: dark chocolate, mocha, fudge, dulche de leche, coffee bitter. Aftertaste: coffee bitterness, some slightly sour touch, ripe cherries.
Smooth for a black.  Not too sweet with a decent aftertaste.  Surprisingly thirst quenching too.

Draft at CAh, pours black with little head and lacing. Nose is mild with roasted malted and molasses.  First sip is nice with black malt, smooth drinking, with coffee andmilk chocolate. Finish is nice most porter like.

Poured 750 ml into tulip glass.  Riich dark brown with a medium sized and persistent head. It has a weighty feel on the tongue and nice carbonation. Chocolate and roast flavors are very prominent, and there is a fleeting taste of bourbon that rounds it out. Overall it is an excellent beer worthy of the description as a "sophisticated stout".

Pours a thin black with a tab fizzy head that leaves barley a trace of lace. A touch over carbonated. Nose and taste are of dark chocolate, spice, subdued hops, roasted malts. A very solid beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap.  Black pour with little head. Aroma of tobacco.  Taste of roasted malts and chocolate.  Medium body medium carbonation.

Bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown with a medium, lasting head.  Aroma is mostly roasted malts and coffee with hints of chocolate and dark fruits.  Flavor is similar to the aroma with hints of yeast.  Smooth finish.  Overall pretty good.

Tasted in August 2011 from a corked and caged 750mL bottle at Lush Roscoe, batch #28.  Pours extremely dark amber, letting just a tint of light through, with a thin tan head that slowly recedes to a thin collar of lace.  The nose is darkly roasted malt, coffee, bitter dark chocolate, and burnt bread.  The flavor is lightly sweet up front, moving to dusty roasted malt, semi-sweet dark chocolate, freshly roasted coffee, and spicy Belgian yeast.  The body is full with average carbonation and a long spicy yeast, dark chocolate, and coffee finish.

Large format, in snifter.  Brownish black and opaque with tan white lacing. Aromas of slight leather, licorace, but not much else. Can almost smell the a hint of coffee coming off the top.  Slight chocolate, roasted, burnt flavors with a bit of sweetness.  Light thin silky mouthfeel with lively small bubble carbonation.  Slight bitter finish. Well balanced, but almost too well.  No specific flavor jumps out.  Glad I tried it, but too expensive and probalby would not have again.

On tap at Jimmy the Greeks in Old Orchard Beach. Served in an Allagash stem glass. Roasty aroma. Medium body. Well hopped. I actually thought this was a Black IPA at first. Not as hoppy though, but more so than youd expect with a stout. Wonderful coffee and chocolate notes with this one. Well done.
Pretty boring stout. It was thin, didnt have much flavor, and was pretty much nothing but roasty malt flavors, and that is really it. Same on the nose. Not exciting by any measure.
Draft. Deep black, turns to brown. Taste us sweet, nutty and thin bodied. Not what I expected from a stout by them, but abv is non present. Very nice to drink

750 ml bottle (Batch 18) purchased almost 15 months ago at Mesa Liquor in San Diego ($10.99).  Pours dark brown with some reddish hints and two fingers of tan head.  Aroma of dusty roasty graininess, toasted dark nutty artisanal bread, milk chocolate, and a hint of warm alcohol.  Flavor of semi-roasty malts, mild dark chocolate, and light low-grade coffee with hints of salty dried meat and stewed dark fruits.  Finishes dry and with some semi-bitter coffee notes.  Very smooth mouthfeel...the Belgian yeast and carbonation give it an interesting character.  (573, 604)

I recall having this before at the Big Hunt on tap and loving it....this particular rating is for a bottle Ive aged for about 18 months....Pours a strangely translucent black with a slight off-white head.  Aroma is roasty coffee.  

I guess I dont know exactly what a foreign stout is supposed to be but I like my stouts with more body.  Its tasty but really really thin for a stout.

Brown to black pour, creamy tan head. Aroma is sweet belgian candy, roasted malts, coffee. Taste is sweet candy, dark malts, chocolate, coffee.  Some alcohol taste is present.  Aftertaste primarily coffee. Nice combination.

Brown/red pour with tan head and lace. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, and a hinto abv. Sweet chocolate notes, with light coffee, a nice warmth, and a decent malt bitter. Medium bodied with a tad fizzy carbonation for me. still a nice beer.

Pours dark brown (shocking) with a large tan head.  Big malty aroma with some coffee, chocolate and bread.  More of the same in the flavor, and really, really smooth for 7.5% alcohol.  Another great beer from a great brewery.
Pours black with a foamy tan head.  Very big chocolate and dark fruit aroma, taste follows with some candi yeast notes.  Very smooth on palate.  Dry coffee finish.  Would drink again.

Pours black with ruby red edges and small tan fizz. Smells of cocoa and dark fruits. Tastes of cocoa and a touch of fruitiness, though primarily it is just dry. Full-bodied with a silky texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Allagash Black finishes with a fruity dryness.

Bottle @ bros house from Bottleworks. Deep black appearance with a brown head with little retention. Sweet creamy, milky, roasty chocolate malt aroma. A little thin, roasty, slightly burnt, chocolate, milky flavor. Roasty milk chocolate aftertaste.

Bottle shared by Dallas, thanks 
Appearance: Dark brown with a medium sized tan head and good lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malts, Belgian yeast and bitter chocolate 
Taste: Roasty, bitter chocolate and coffee 
Nice

750mL bottle.  Pours almost completely opaque with a foamy tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, yeast, other sweet & burnt notes, and a bit of booze.  Taste is similar, with more yeast presence than on the nose.  A bit sticky mouthfeel.

pours a dark brown, with an off-white/beige head.  Aroma is roasty-yeasty, with a cooled dark coffee character.  Taste begins with maybe more chocolate than coffee, with a distinctive belgian ale backdrop.  Definitely more dark chocolate in the finish; an enjoyable bitterness.  A really great belgian-style stout.
pours hazy dark brown with a nice beige head, good retention and lacing. nice roasted nose, yeast and spices. belgian carbonation, medium to full body.
UPDATED: FEB 2, 2015 At Fork on Lincoln. Brownish black slightly sweet stout with coffee taste and aroma. Easy to drink for its strength. Flavors come together nicely. Serving: Tap

Sample, Mondial de la bière, savoured on June 8 2011; eye: black, opaque, tiny ring of off-white head; nose: roasted malt, dark chocolate, light coffee, light malt; mouth: roasted malt, dark chocolate, acridness, light sugar, finale in roasted malt with presence of toffee, medium body, average carbonation, lightly sweet, a bit thin; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS 

Échantillon, Mondial de la bière, savourée le 10 juin 2011; il : noire, opaque, petit anneau de mousse blanc cassé; nez : malt torréfié, chocolat noir, léger café, léger malt; bouche : malt torréfié, chocolat noir, âcreté, léger sucre, finale en malt torréfié avec présence de toffee, corps moyen, carbonatation moyenne, légèrement sucrée, un peu mince; en résumé : bien

Aroma of dark chocolate shavings and black coffee.  Pours close to black with a medium.but thick head (thanks to the nitro).  Tastes of roasted coffee with hints of chocolate.  Finishes with a sweet iron taste thanks to the Belgian yeast.  Great stout!

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2013 Bottle 750ml @ Hotel Room, Hacienda Hotel LAX, El Segundo, CA
Pours dark brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, chocolate, yeast and dried fruits. Taste is medium sweet and light to medium bitter with a long caramel and dried fruity finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.
Pour is jet black with a small tan. Nose is of burnt coffee. Taste is much sweeter and of chocolate. Fairly smooth for 7.5% and an easy drinker.

At a tasting, thanks Shahar, pours brown to black with a nice brown head, aroma of nuts, wood, cocoa and lentils, flavor is smoked with some chocolate, dried fruits, cherries and coffee in the aftertaste, lively carbonation medium to full bodied, very nice

Bottle at a tasting. Thanks beerandbeyond. Dark brown to black-colored with a beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, nuts and some fruitiness. Burnt roasty flavor with coffee. Medium to full-bodied. Decent.
Pours black. Coffee & chocolate on the nose wiith a little baking spice. Palate is even, nicely balanced and rich without being heavy. Delicious!

DRAFT pour at Fork in Lincoln Square / Chicago.  Very much smoother / more mild than expected.  Interesting notes of chocolate and expresso; not overpowering but definitely there.  Think I need to try this one again for more full review....
